required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Project TECH (Teens Engaged in Collaborative Health)
clinical_study.official_title: Project TECH (Teens Engaged in Collaborative Health)

brief_summary.textblock: The mission of this project is to develop novel systems of care that can provide efficacious, scalable, cost-effective, participant friendly technology assisted behavioral interventions (TABIs) for the prevention of depression in adolescents. The investigators define TABIs as interventions that use information and telecommunications technologies such as the internet, mobile or traditional phones, computers and/or other technologies to support and deliver psychological and behavioral interventions.

detailed_description.textblock:
Depression is common, debilitating, costly, and frequently begins in adolescence or young adulthood. RCTs of face-to-face (FtF) therapy show efficacy, but this often does not translate to clinical practice. Barriers to treatment are the norm: More that 75% of depressed adults and youth cannot access care due to structural barriers (cost, transportation problems, time constraints, lack of available services,etc.). To overcome barriers, internet treatments have been examined but effect sizes remain modest, ranging from d=.25 to d=.61 due at least in part to low levels of utilization and adherence.
The first aim of this project will be to conduct focus interviews and usability testing of three technologies with adolescents: "Networked Peer Support", "Smart Phone Application" and "Virtual Humans". All three technologies use similar methods that involve adaptation of technologies followed by usability and beta-testing.
The second aim of this project will be to complete a field trial of the intervention based on feedback received from the focus interviews and usability testing.
The objective of this study is:
1. To collect qualitative data from focus interviews with adolescents on their telecommunication technology usage patterns, and the ways in which telecommunication technology can support behavior change.
2. To develop and beta test a networked peer support website, smart phone applications, and a web-based virtual human to prevent depression in adolescents.
3. To collect pilot data on adherence and usability of the applications, websites and tools.
4. To collect pilot data on the efficacy of a web-based intervention with a social network to reduce risk of depression

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Endpoint Classification: Efficacy Study, Intervention Model: Parallel Assignment, Masking: Single Blind (Outcomes Assessor), Primary Purpose: Prevention

primary_outcome.time_frame: Throughout participation, lasting up to 26 weeks
primary_outcome.description: Depression as measured by the Center for Epidemiologic Studies Depression Scale (CES-D) and depression module of the Mini International Neuropsychiatric Interview for Children and Adolescents (MINIKid)

primary_outcome.time_frame: Throughout participation, lasting up to 26 weeks
primary_outcome.description: Usability of the program as measured by the Usefulness, Satisfaction, and Ease of Use (USE) survey.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Has a score of 0-29 on the Center for Epidemiologic Studies Depression Scale
- Is familiar with the use of computers and the Internet, as well as mobile phones
- Is able to speak and read English
- Is between 14-19 years of age
Exclusion Criteria:
- Is currently taking an antidepressant medication or has taken one in the previous 3 months
- Has visual, hearing, voice, or motor impairment that would prevent completion of study procedures or use of the Internet or mobile phone
- Is diagnosed with a psychotic disorder, bipolar disorder, dissociative disorder, current substance dependence, or other diagnosis for which participation in this trial is either inappropriate or dangerous
- Is severely suicidal (has ideation, plan, and intent).

responsible_party.investigator_title: Director, Center for Behavioral Intervention Technologies; Professor, Department of Preventive Medicine
